segments.text: Make sure it's fully plugged in.
Okay, this is Ron Shorn on Wednesday, June 2, 1993, at the University of Texas at Austin Astronomy Department, and I'm talking with Larry Trafton.
So, for the record, Larry, would you give your full name?
Lawrence Monroe Trafton.
Okay.
Okay.
And where were you born and when?
Boston, Massachusetts, 1938, July 31st.
How did you first get interested in astronomy?

I can remember being interested in astronomy in the second grade, walking out on a cold winter's night somewhere in Massachusetts from an Eaton's drugstore and recognizing the constellation Orion in the winter sky.
which I just read about in a book written for children on the constellations.
So that reaffirmed my faith in the reality of the written material on constellations.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
Caltech.
What was your major?
Astronomy.
And what year did you graduate?
Why did you decide to pick astronomy as a major rather than?
Oh, I knew by the time I was a teenager I wanted to be an astronomer.
I was an amateur, and I'd ground and polished my own six-inch mirror, built my own telescope.
I was building and assembling telescopes in the sixth grade and seventh grade.
So astronomy was one of my early interests.
In freshman year, I briefly considered geology and some other majors, just because I knew I'd be making this lifetime decision.
I said, nah, I'll stick with astronomy.
Why did you go to Caltech?
Because they were the, I figured it was the best school available in the world for an education in astronomy.
They ran, of course, Mount Wilson, Mount Palomar, and had an excellent reputation.
Okay, where did you go to grad school?
Also Caltech, for the same reasons.
Okay.
Who was your thesis advisor?
Guido Munch.
Did you pick him, or did he pick you, or was it mutual?
I went around the department talking to the various professors about a topic for my thesis.
That previous summer I worked at JPL doing a literature review on Jupiter, and Guido mentioned a topic in planetary atmospheres, solar system.
And that picked my interest.
I was also very interested in the space program at the time.
And so I decided to pursue a thesis in solar system rather than in some other general field in astronomy.
OK. What did your thesis consist of?
It consisted, well, its title was pretty descriptive, Study of Energy Balance in the Atmospheres of the Major Planets.
And its nucleus was applying the pressure-induced
opacity of hydrogen and helium in the structure of the atmospheres of the major planets.
In other words, it, for the first time, used this opacity as a thermal opacity for determining the pressure-temperature structure.
Now, after you got your PhD, you got a job, and you must have been thinking about it before you were quite finished.
or was your first job after you got out of grad school?

At Kirtland Air Force Base in Albuquerque, New Mexico, fulfilling an ROTC commitment, Air Force ROTC, I was in charge of an Earth-orbiting satellite with 12 or 13 experiments on board to measure the hazard that solar flare particle radiation would pose to a military astronaut, a so-called MAL, manned orbiting vehicle astronaut.
That program was canceled by McNamara,
I think in the late 60s, but at the time the military had an interest in Ph.D. level astronomers, particularly those specializing in the solar system for that purpose.
Okay, and then where did you go after that?
University of Texas at Austin.
How come here?
Well, this was actually one of three choices.
Another choice was with Kuiper's group in Arizona.
And the third choice may have been at Flagstaff, as I recall.
At Lowell?
At Lowell, or with Bob Weldy.
At USGS?
At USGS.
And I figured that I would need a place with a good computer, good access to telescopes, a good research library.
And I was communicating with Harlan Smith at the time.
And UT came across as being the most
having the most potential for a career in research.
My goal was to do research rather than to teach.
How did you get in touch with Harlan in the first place?
Oh.
I mean, did you just meet somewhere, or did you write him a letter?
The first time I ever met Harlan Smith was when I was having a restaurant on Route 3 in Massachusetts, eating at a restaurant somewhere between Boston and Cape Cod on Route 3.
And out of the blue, Guido Munch and Harlan Smith, I guess they were returning from a meeting in Woods Hole or something, recognized me and came over and sat down.
Guido introduced me to Harlan Smith, who at the time, I think, was secretary of the AAS.
And as I recall, he invited me to come see, I can't remember what, if ever I was in town.
That's my first recollection.
When was that?
That was about 1962.
Okay, when you were still a grad student.
That's right, when I was still a grad student.
When did you get your PhD?
In 65.
65, okay.
Was working that summer at JPL the first time you got associated with NASA money, or had you done some other stuff before that?
Of course, Caltech runs JPL, and I was working there for the summer as a Caltech student
I think it was two summers that I worked there.
I think it was right after my senior year.
I think it was two consecutive years in graduate school.
Not after I graduated, but after my first graduate years is when I worked there.
And one of those years, I worked for Hiram Spinrad.
I think it was the second year.
And the first year, I did a review on Jupiter for Ray Newbern.
What have you been doing since you've been to Texas, if you can summarize the general kind of work?

Basically observational and some theoretical research in astronomy, almost entirely solar system astronomy, specializing in the outer planets and their atmospheres and those with satellites having atmospheres, particularly high-resolution spectroscopy.
in more recent years, branching out into the infrared and ultraviolet astronomy.
Since 1977, I'm involved with the Hubble Space Telescope on the instrument definition team for the high-resolution spectrograph.
And just recently, data has been coming down from the Hubble.
I'm involved not only as a guaranteed time observer for my service on the team, but also as a so-called general observer, competing with other astronomers for time on the Hubble.
It's branched out.
What would you say was the... Well, let's start this way.
Do you feel planetary astronomy is part of astronomy?
Very definitely.
And you consider yourself an astronomer?
Yes, even an astrophysicist.
Do you think real quote-unquote astronomers look down on planetary astronomers?
If they're on...
Another world looking towards the Earth, yes.
There are those that would say that planetary astronomy is looked on as a pariah by stellar and extragalactic.
Well, there have been periods in the history of astronomy where people have thought that solar system astronomy has been mined out.
One of those was after the 1930s, for example, when it was discovered that life didn't exist on Mars.
conditions were not hospitable to life on some of the other planets.
And so astronomers at that time would naturally turn their attention to more distant objects.
Comets were included as distant objects, even though now we consider them as part of solar system astronomy.
So comets were always considered in good favor by the mainstream astronomical community.
Of course, for the advent of NASA, there's been a renaissance in planetary and solar system astronomy, which is very multidisciplinary.
I mean, it involves not just astronomers, but geologists, exobiologists, astrochemists.
And so I think there's a lot of respect for solar system astronomy because it is so multidisciplinary and is known, therefore, well-known among a number of fields.
But as for your traditional astronomer, I think they do
consider planetary astronomy to be somewhat different from what they do.
What was planetary astronomy like back in the 60s when you got into it?
Back in the 60s, it was high-resolution spectroscopy with photographic plates, ammoniated plates to increase sensitivity in the near-infrared, namely beyond about 7,800 angstroms, 7,000 angstroms.
pre-flash plates to increase sensitivity in the visual region, or baking plates in ovens to do the same thing.
There were also photomultipliers, the famous RCA-31-whatever.
Oh, photomultiplier.
1P21, that's it, yeah.
The 31-something was a later photomultiplier, too.
Single-channel devices for scanning one wavelength at a time or for obtaining the
magnitudes through various filters.
Astronomy in those days was very much a one-man thing.
One man went out and he did the entire project himself at the telescope over a period of nights.
He reduced the data and he published the data.
The equipment was less expensive, less complicated.
There were hardly any computers either running or reducing the data in those days.
There was a lot of
independency among astronomers.
Astronomers are very independent people.
The person next door could be doing research which is totally unrelated to yours.
No consortia, such as with the Hubble's nowadays.
Very independent, very personal.
Funding was relatively easy to get, and it didn't take a whole lot of funding to do a research project.
There was still a lot to be discovered, particularly in planetary astronomy, which had been neglected for so many years.
And with the advent of new telescopes like the one at McDonald, the 2.7 meter, there was now guaranteed time to spend a certain amount of telescope time on astronomical observations.
I think that may have been, by the way, another factor in my coming to Texas, the fact that I know I could get time on a big telescope to do astronomical observations.
Up to that time, the number of big telescopes were limited.
And I remember doing some observations from the 100-inch and 60-inch at Mount Wilson.
But you had to compete with the regular astronomers for time to do astronomy in those days.
Would you say that NASA's bucks were critical to reinvigorating planetary astronomy?
Played an enormous role.
I mean, a number of telescopes were built, the McDonnell Telescope, the IRTF, and corresponding instrumentation designed towards doing
astronomy of extended sources, the type of high-resolution spectroscopy, the kind of astronomy that is useful for planetary work.
And also, about that time, the computer became noticed.
And I think the space program and NASA, and NASA dollars in particular, have certainly applied the spinoff from computers in the area of astronomy in particular, ground-based planetary astronomy.
And then, of course, there's been the advent of space-based planetary astronomy, which is the IUE with its fantastic record.
I think IUE is still going after how many years?
I mean, that's not just planetary astronomy, but that's where the first looks, that's where the Joving Aurora was discovered and some other areas in planetary astronomy.
Where do you think planetary astronomy is?
What shape is it in now, and which way is it going?
Well, planetary astronomy has really come a long way.
Spacecraft have visited all the planets except Pluto, and there is planning for even a vast Pluto flyby mission in the works.
There's the Hubble Space Telescope, which has finally been launched, and looking not only at planets, but the rest of astronomical objects.
IUE is still going.
What there has been a great deceleration on is the plans for future space missions, future missions to do astronomy.
The concept that's small, better, cheaper, faster is now dominating the huge flagship-type missions such as Galileo and Ulysses.
There's an enormous funding crunch that's being felt at all levels in the government.
It's being felt
in planetary or solar system astronomy.
There's been some competition with the things like the space station, but I think things like the space station are inevitable.
That's part of human destiny.
I think most of the friction between astronomers today, between those varying the space station and unmanned facilities, are based mainly on funding.
They assume that if the space station is canceled, for example, there will be that much more money
for ground-based unmanned astronomy.
I don't think that necessarily follows.
Funding is a big problem, and it may get worse before it gets better.
But I still think there is a lot to do in solar system science from the ground and from the space.
What do you consider the most worthwhile thing you did in planetary astronomy?
The most worthwhile thing?
Yeah, you might have to carve something on your tombstone, would you?
Oh, my gosh.
I guess one candidate is my thesis work, recognizing the thermal, being able to calculate the thermal structure of the planets.
A lot of little things, little discoveries here and there concerning composition, various things such as Neo's atmosphere or Titan, work in Pluto.
It's hard to put my finger on any one thing, but a whole collection of little things.
Just gradual progress here and there from infrared, visible, and ultra-valid astronomy.
Progress along a broad front at one step at a time in many different areas.
A lot of irons in the fire.
In the past, there was some concern that if planetary people got their own sub-society,
they would get cut off from normal astronomy.
Well, they did get the DPS, the Division for Planetary Sciences, and their own captive journal, Icarus.
In your opinion, have these been good things or bad things?
Well, at the time all this was happening, there was an explosion in journals throughout science.
I mean, I think the number of journals increased by more than an order of magnitude.
the time Icarus came online and the time it was adopted as being the official journal of the society.
So even within the remainder of astronomy, there are the advent of new journals.
So I don't think that solar system astronomy stands out as being different from everybody else in this respect.
I think this was going on everywhere.
And therefore, it doesn't taint planetary astronomy in any way.
Do planetary astronomers talk to other types of astronomers about the same as they did when you started out, more or less?

I would say at first less, but now it's starting to be more and more because things have developed so much in both areas, in regular astronomy and planetary astronomy, that people are starting to examine the interface.
Do other stars have planets?
What about Oort clouds around other stars?
Can they be studied from the vicinity of the Earth?
People, with the advent of advanced instrumentation, advanced infrared instrumentation and detectors, people have been able to study observationally regions of star formation.
And some of the problems in planetary astronomy, the big problem in planetary astronomy is what is the origin of the solar system?
How did it evolve?
How did the atmospheres and so forth evolve?
And you can ask the same questions about what's going on in star formation.
How are these stars being formed?
Are planets necessarily being formed around them or not?

So I see a collision course between the scientific objectives of solar system astronomy and astronomy in general, particularly that involved with the interstellar medium and star formation and infrared astronomy.
I think that ultimately there will be a merging of interests of people.
You may find people doing research in both areas.
What's the current status of planetary astronomy here at the University of Texas?
Is it a little separate kingdom?
Is it growing, shrinking, just staying out of the way, doing great things, or what?
It's a close-knit group.
The planetary group here is really close
knit, but I would characterize it as being largely isolated from the rest of the department.
I mean, people go and sit in each other's seminars and listen to what's going on.
We have a solar system seminar.
Now and then we will get some people from the other departments, but not very often.
There is also an intermediate group which deals with dynamics of solar system bodies.
They come to our group.
We know what
each other is doing in the fields, but I would say that there's probably a minor boundary between that and those who... Who would you consider the planetary group here in Austin?
Well, Bill Cochran, Anita Cochran, Ed Barker is still doing research in planetary astronomy, myself, graduate Whipple next door.
Fred Whipple.
No, no, Art Whipple.
Judith Gorgi, a graduate student who just got her Ph.D. Paul Hemingway.
Jeffries does some dynamical work.
There is a sub-dynamical group, but I would broadly include them in solar system.
Pete Shalas.
Perhaps Fred Benedict.
What about Smolichowski?
And Smolichowski, of course, very definitely.
So you're no danger of extinction here or anything like that?
No, not in the near term, anyway.
What kind of NASA funding have you had over the years?
I don't need all the details.
Well, out of Brunk's program has been our main source.
Were you funded out of that block grant for a number of years?
Bronx Block grant out of the Planetary Astronomy Program.
That grant had been in place a couple of years when I came here in 1969.
And it was converted to individual grants, I think, in 1991.
In 1991, it ended, and each one of us had to submit individual grants.
I think that was a step backwards, because now we all have to do our own administration.
We all have to write, parallel our own annual reports.
and keep track of the accounting.
We can't use the economies of scale.
Those of us who are especially good at accounting do the accounting for the entire block.
Those of us who are good at writing reports do the report writing for the entire block.
Everything has to be done in parallel by everyone involved.
And I think NASA is getting less for its money as a result of this reduction.
It lost an economy of scale.
I was going to ask, do you have any gripes?
And there's one right there.
There's one right there.
Do you think that people at headquarters really understand what you're doing?
I've had the feeling in the past, talking with Brunk and with Juergen Rahe, that they actually do keep up.
They actually do have an idea of what I'm doing.
Also, in Juergen's particular case, he is also an editor on
volumes, like this Time Variable Phenomena in the Jovian System, where I publish some of my results.
So he gets to see some of the stuff I do, not only from the reports I submit.
And he's very interested in getting these reports, so I assume he reads them.
But he also gets them from the literature that he's involved with himself.
I also had the feeling that Brunk kept up with what I was doing.
I noticed, perhaps, maybe
slowed down in the period that he was involved very heavily with the development of the IRTF.
He seemed to get a little more remote from what we and perhaps others were doing around that period.
But I understand he was heavily involved with the IRTF at the time it was being built.
Well, here's two questions about the public.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job selling themselves to the public?
I think that many of them are doing a good job in selling themselves to the public.
We have something at McDonald Observatory called Public Night, once a week when the public can come in and hear a program which includes a talk by the astronomer of the night.
And when I've been that astronomer, I've given a 15-minute talk on what I've been doing in solar system astronomy, and then I spend another 10 to 15 minutes answering questions.
And those questions, judging from the kind and tone of those questions, people are very interested.
in what's going on.
They genuinely are curious to know what's going on in planetary astronomy.
Back when I was an undergraduate in the late 50s, I was a guide at the Griffith Observatory and also experienced the same genuine interest by the public in what goes on in the stars and the fields.
A really deep curiosity
I have a lot of faith in the public's interest in astronomy and solar system astronomy in particular, just based on my own personal experiences.

I've also attended star parties, dropped in on star parties at McDonnell Observatories and seen the long lines in front of even the little telescopes way out there in the middle of nowhere in West Texas.
There are people in the planetary astronomy field who are seeking and in some cases getting money.
by studying hot current topics like ozone, for lack thereof, search for extraterrestrial intelligence, planets around other stars, and killer asteroids.
Do you think that's a good idea, or do you think it'll backfire?
Do you think some are good and some aren't?
I see no harm in a certain amount of that, but I would not like to see that become a large
part of the focus of planetary astronomy.
I would not like to see NASA develop too much towards looking back towards Earth.
One of their programs is called Mission to Planet Earth.
I think that would be a mistake to make that too big a part of their program, because I think that would lose a lot of the romance that the exploration of space has among your average public.
I think that people do want to go out into space
to know what's out there and eventually to send people out there.
And I think if you make the program too practical, too much like other programs that exist in the nation, then that will actually hurt NASA.
And by parallel argument, I think it may even hurt astronomy or planetary astronomy.
If we make our programs too much like they were prepared for the front page of a newspaper rather than for
scholarly journal.
There are some people that feel that NASA never has given enough money for analysis of the data once they got the pretty pictures in.
Have you found that to be true?
That's been a bone of contention in some quarters since NASA started.
At the very early days of the space program, I definitely had the feeling that the glory lay in the launches, not with what happened after the launch, not with the data that was collected.
I saw this when I was in the Air Force.
The Air Force was launching its own satellites, and there was a lot of glory and attention in everything that led up to the launch, and a sudden decline in interest in what happened afterwards.
I think NASA has been somewhat sensitive to this argument and has generally tried to apply
funds to the extension of duration of missions and for the reduction of data afterwards.
But I think in many cases that wasn't enough.
I think that it's a lot cheaper, for example, to keep funding a spacecraft going around Venus while it's working and getting additional data than it is to build another spacecraft and send it there.
I mean, if it's working, it's cheap to continue getting data.
I'm glad to see that they still try to get data from the voyages.
that are near the, what is it, the magnetopause of the solar system, and even now finding out new things.
Getting closer.
However, I think there's a tradeoff between people who want to do new things and start new projects and people who want to get full value for projects already existing.
And I think you will always see this throughout human history in any field.
And the question is, is there going to be an equilibrium line where everybody's going to be happy?
No.
But my personal opinion is I would have liked to have seen more
support for reduction and careful analysis of data that had already been obtained.
We found out a lot of things about the planets and the solar system in general since the space age began, both from space and from the ground.
Can you give a general idea of what planetary astronomy has done?
thing like, well, we now know there's more than one kind of planet, or some statement like that.
I'm leaving it vague so you can make up what you want to say.
Well, one surprise for me was to see the craters on absolutely everything without an atmosphere in the solar system.
I mean, craters in the backside of Mercury, craters in the satellites of Saturn, craters everywhere.
I thought the moon had a corner on the crater market before the advent of the space program.

This has really hammered home how the planetesimals were flying around in the early days of the solar system when it was being formed, and has really illuminated the conditions and the formation of the solar system.

We also now have a much better idea of what the primordial solar nebula must have been like based on isotope studies of the terrestrial planets and studies of the outer planets, and most recently with the composition of Pluto and Triton are only real keys to what the solar
was out in the outer solar system, inside the orb belt and such.
So I think we have a much better idea of how the solar system formed and the planets formed, although a lot of unanswered questions.
How atmospheres formed and evolved and how secondary atmospheres developed.
I think we have much, much better idea in the geology of the surfaces of bodies, satellites, terrestrial bodies throughout the solar system than we had before.

We have deeper insights into the cryogenic atmospheres of Mars, Triton, and Pluto, planets whose atmospheres are controlled by the vapor pressure of ices on their surface, and how these atmospheres might vary with seasons.
We have a whole lot better idea of what the detailed composition of even complex organics are in places like Titan, Jupiter, Saturn.
even Venus.
We have so much data.
Often we have the situation when you answer one question, it raises two more questions.
And I think we've been running on a roll unlike that.
I think we're still in the situation.
Yes, we've learned an awful lot, but now we recognize there's so much we don't understand, and we would like to get some more answers.
How much of an effect do you think

The fact that we haven't found any traces of life anywhere else in the solar system but Earth, and in particular not on Mars, how much do you think that affected funding and public interest for planetary astronomy?
Oddly enough, when I mentioned Horowitz experiments for detecting life on Mars, explaining how difficult it is to design an experiment to detect life
without making assumptions in what form that life takes, I find that people are actually turned on by the search for life.
They're not turned off by the failure so far to discover life.
They're fascinated by how would you design an experiment to detect life in general?
I mean, not life as we know it.
And the fascination, for example, that of all the possible amino acids, only about half of them have been found on Earth.
another one of those 26 or 28 were found elsewhere and not found on Earth, that would imply independent origin of life.
They still seem to find that fascinating.
I don't really see a lot of people turned off by the failure so far to detect life.
I see them almost eagerly accepting the challenge to search in more creative ways for it.
It may not exist on Mars, but maybe it once did.
If so, what was it like?
Could there be fossilized evidence of that sitting somewhere in the Martian rocks?
People seem to be fascinated by questions like that and would like to see the answers.
I think, go ahead, what you just said.
Harland Smith is the best money raiser I've ever known.

Back in the, especially in the first 10 years that I've been at UT, he, more than anybody else, has been enormously successful in raising money and going and personally talking to members of Congress and lobbying for astronomy and for space astronomy in particular.
In fact, when I first came to Texas, he told me the two things he wanted to accomplish at UT was to develop a first-class astronomy department and to introduce it into space exploration and research.
In the final years, we were trying to raise money for the big telescopes.
He wasn't quite as successful.
Yeah, the 300-inch came awful close, I guess, the last hour of the legislature or something.
But it seemed like he had a magic touch in those first 10 or 15 years.
Well, it certainly helps if you can raise money.
Yes.
